What Is Easing? Using Easing Equations Available Easings

Plunder's Easings

This section goes into detail about the easing equations that are available in Plunder. Click here for the main Plunder documentation.

What Is Easing?

Easing is a means of applying a smoothing to an animation, typically a movement. The input to the easing equation is the current state of the animation, and the output is where the animation should be according to the chosen equation. Each equation gives the animation a different type of movement. They are commonly used to smooth movement and get rid of jerky, hard edged movement caused by just moving things linearly

Using Easing Equations

To use an easing equation, specify its name as an option to a Plunder animation call: 

var entity = new MyGameEntity();
var timeline = new Timeline(entity);
timeline.tween({
   property: 'myProperty',
   from: 10,
   to: 100,
   easing: 'quadInOut'
});

Available Easings

Below is a demonstration of all the easing equations available in Plunder. The graph gives a visual indication of how the easing equation progresses. The orange square shows an entity moving across under that easing, and the grey one next to it is using linear easing to compare against.

The easing implementation was taken from Jim Jeffers's Easie, which is a port of Robert Penner's easing equations ported to CoffeeScript.

A note on the linear equations

You may have noticed that linear, linearIn, linearOut, linearInOut and linearNone all do the same thing. They are all included for completion's sake. Generally if you need linear easing you are fine just specifying linear (or nothing at all, as linear is the default)
